ROBERT FIELD: We
are exciting a band.

So you're exciting from
low vibrational levels to relatively high
vibrational level. And this then fluoresces
very far to the red.

There'll also be some
blue fluorescence from the two turning points. And so going from one
vibrational level to another,

the ratio of intensity in the
blue and the red can change.

And so usually these effects
of the sensitivity range

of the photomultiplier
are quantitative.

They don't make
a line disappear, but they make the
intensities of transition

that occur in the same
region of the spectrum be different from
what you expect.

AUDIENCE: Can you ever use
that to your advantage? ROBERT FIELD: Yes. AUDIENCE: By having
two photomultipliers? ROBERT FIELD: Yes.

One often uses two
photomultipliers and usually use some kind
of filter, which will divide

the spectrum into two channels. And the relationship
between the two channels

provides you with information
and a way of sorting. You can also have a
local perturbation.

So here is a term value curve,
and here's another term value
curve. This is energy versus taking x1.

And suppose this
state is bright. It has a short lifetime. It's the state that
you're exciting to.

This is dark. You can't excite. You can't have an
allowed transition from the initial
state into this.

It has a long lifetime. And near where
these levels cross, you get an avoided
crossing like this.

And the states
are schizophrenic. The levels have intermediate
radiative properties.

And so you will end up seeing
lines with anomalous intensity,

with anomalous frequencies,
and maybe more lines than you expect. So perturbations
can also affect--

So there are many
effects that corrupt

the relative intensities. And you can also be
doing an experiment

like resonance enhanced
multiphoton ionization.

So instead of looking
at fluorescence, well, it could be exciting
to some intermediate state,

and then with a second
laser, ionizing. And that's also
not indiscriminate.

So now, instead of
looking at a photon--

so you excite here, and
there's a laser always present that causes that
state to ionize.

And so if this state does
something, again, goes away by fluorescence or
predissociation,

you can still have
intensity anomalies due to quantum yield and
being other than 100%.

So there's lots of
ways in which intensity in a laser-induced fluorescence
or a REMPE spectrum, where your

scanning the
frequency of the laser is different from just the
absorption coefficient.
OK.

So when you do a spectrum like
an LIF or a REMPE spectrum,

you have the same
problem you did with the classical spectrum.

You get the whole spectrum. And there isn't any
sorting, so you don't really know how to assign it.

It's just as hard. In fact, it's harder,
because instead of having the whole
spectrum all at once,

you have to slowly
scan your laser and you record the spectrum and
you're wasting a lot of time.

Because instead of getting
100,000 resolution elements in one shot, you're getting
a resolution element

every second or so.  But you still haven't
done any sorting.
So there's a very simple idea.

And that's dispersed
fluorescence. So you have your laser
populating some upper state.

And you're not tuning
the laser anymore. You've tuned it to
a fluorescence line,

and you stop. And now, you look
at the fluorescence from this upper level. And so this is a level,
which you would like

to know its quantum numbers. And all you know
when you start is

that you've excited it with
some fluorescence from a level. And you might even have, as you
scanned on your LIF spectrum,

you said, oh, this looks like
a nice sharp single line,

I'd like to know who it is.  And so you stop, and
you say, OK, now I'm

going to do a new experiment. I'm going to take
the fluorescence and put it into a
micrometer, or spectrometer,

and measure the spectrum
of the fluorescence. And so what you see is a
series of pairs of lines.

And what you see in
the spectrum is nothing but combination differences. So the thing that
you've had to work on

in the classical
spectrum is given to you on a silver platter.

That the dispersed fluorescent
spectrum contains nothing but what you wanted to know.

So it's a fantastic
simplification. And so you see a
spectrum that normally

looks like a progression
of pairs of lines. And so these are p and r lines
that come from a common j,

and from the spacing of
them, one knows something.

Let's call j. This is the pj plus 1 line. And this is the rj
they minus 1 line.

Yes? AUDIENCE: So technically
you still have to scan your
monochrometer to get that?

ROBERT FIELD: Yes. AUDIENCE: Same as
your scanning laser? ROBERT FIELD: Well, first,
you scan your laser to a line,

and then you stop. And then you scan
the monochrometer, unless you have
a detector, which

is a two dimensional detector. And that's wonderful, because
now, what you're doing

is you're actually measuring
the total intensity in each of the lines.

And the intensities
are meaningful, because it doesn't
depend on what the laser was doing as you were
scanning the monochrometer.

And most dispersed fluorescence
experiments these days are not done by scanning
the monochrometer.

They are done with
a CCD detector. And it's just a
television camera. And it says, I see two lines.

AUDIENCE: Did people ever do
dispersed fluorescence spectra

with lasers and
photographic plates? ROBERT FIELD: Yes, I did that.

It's really stupid. But it wasn't
photographic plates. You remember the
Polaroid camera?

That's what you use.  So you waited a few seconds
and you developed this thing

and you measure with a ruler
on this still-wet piece of film for that whole thing.

But it's much easier to-- I mean we also used
chart recorders.

You didn't even know what a
chart recorder is, do you? In fact, one of the first
things I bought at MIT

was a two pen chart
recorder, because I wanted to record the spectrum
and the standard lines.

I'm going to say,
[INAUDIBLE] good look at you. In fact, I think I
had a four pen chart recorder at one point.

you basically never taking data. It's because the stupid
detector isn't working. Not because anything
complicated,

like a laser or the
molecular source. And so this is where
my conservatism

about loading up and
experiment with peripheral junk that might not work.

You know the hard thing
should be the laser and the source of molecules. And everything else
would be 100% reliable.

Chart recorders
ruined my perspective.

Anyway, so you get this
progression of pairs of lines. And so you can calculate from
the rotational energy level

formula that the
spacing between lines is going to be b double
prime, the rotational constant of the lower state,
times 4j prime plus 2,

the quantum number
of the upper state. And so if you know b
double prime, then j.

If you know j, you
know b double prime. You don't know either
when you start.

And so you do this. If you tune the laser
to a line, and then you

tune the laser to
the next line that looks like it belongs
to the same pattern.

So you want to look at two
consecutive lines of a branch. Your eye tells you, yeah,
that looks like a pattern,

I believe it's a pattern. I look at two consecutive
lines, and if the pr separations

change by an amount
reasonable for a change of 4n,

then you say, they were
the same two lines. And you know 4b, and you know j.

So two measurements. You look at the dispersed
fluorescence from one line

and then what you
think is the next line. And if you're not
unlucky, then you

have a complete rotational
assignment of the spectrum.

So these give you the
rotational consent

of some vibrational state. This is the rotational constant,
and the next vibrational state and so on.

And this is the
vibrational frequency. You also don't know which
vibrational quantum number it

is, and so there's another
feature in the pattern that you have to dig out.

Now, there are ways you can
make vibrational assignments.

I'll say something
briefly about that. One is you see a
progression like this,

and you want to follow
that progression to the lowest possible
vibrational level, b equals 0.

So that will be following
the progression to the blue. And if the progression goes as
a series of lines to the blue,

and that ends abruptly, as
opposed to just dying out, you're pretty sure you
found b equals zero.

But if it's dying
out, you don't really know that you got to zero.

But there are other patterns. If you look at a long
vibrational progression, which

is presented to you on a
silver platter as you know. Nothing but combination
differences.

You see all of these
things that are associated with different
vibration levels. And you could say, well,
this is a progression

in the same electronic state. Well, then you can see that
the progression has nodes.

And so the number of
nodes is very likely

to be the vibrational quantum
number for the upper state.

And there are other ways you
can use this information. But once the spectrum
has been simplified

to a simple thing associated
with each vibrational state,

you pretty much can
do fantastic things.

OK, so we have now
this progression. We determined b from the
change in the pr separation.

And in order to be able
to make j assignments, we need a resolution,
or a precision,

for pr separations,
which is roughly 2b.

Because you want to be
able to, since they change in steps before b,
you want to be sure

that your accuracy
is one unit of j or better than a half unit of j.

And a typical monochrometer
that you would use for this

would be something like
a .75 meter instrument

with a 1,200 groove
per milliliter rating.

And that has a dispersion
of about 10 angstroms per millimeter.

And so you can make the slits
be about 10 microns before you

starting to kill yourself. When you make the
slits too small,

you smear out the image
because of the fraction. And so 10 microns is OK
for visible radiation.

So 10 microns is a
hundredth of a millimeter.

And so you can have a
resolution on the order
of a tenth of an angstrom.  And what's an angstrom?

AUDIENCE: How do you
make that calculation?

How does the size of the
grading effect the resolution? ROBERT FIELD: I didn't say
anything about the grading.

So this is a typical number. And it comes from the
diffraction equation,

but it also comes from my memory
that typical monochrometers are

either .75 meters or 1 meter. They have 1,200 groove
per millimeter grading, and this is the number
that you typically know.

I mean, if you work
in second order, well, then you get 5
angstroms per millimeter.

Or if you have a
2,400 groove grading, it's 5 angstroms per
millimeter in first order.

Now, if it's a lot of grooves,
it's a holographic grading, and they don't work very
well in second order.

So this is a useful
number to store.

OK. But the next number-- electronic transitions
are, let's say

30,000 wavenumbers,
3,000 angstroms.

Well, that's interesting. It's a factor 10 there. So if you have a
tenth of an angstrom

you have one reciprocal
centimeter resolution.

So that's typical
what you can get with this sort of an instrument.

About one reciprocal
centimeter resolution. You can measure things to
better than the resolution

And so you can do better
than the resolution. You can do better
than the resolution by the resolution divided
by the signal of noise

if they're single
symmetric lines. And so you can with
this sort of instrument

have a precision
on a pr separation of a maybe 2/10 or 3/10 of
a reciprocal centimeter.

And as long as b is larger than
6/10 a reciprocal centimeter

here, it'll work. But there are a lot of molecules
with b smaller than that, and then you have to
work a little harder.

So this is pretty good for
most classes of experiments,

but it's right on the edge when
b is a 1/10 of a centimeter.

But one of the
things is that you

have an interplay between
this crude instrument, the monochrometer,
and your laser.

Your laser, you can
measure line setters

on the order of 3/1000
of a wavenumber. That's with the CW laser.

And again, even
with a pulse laser, which has a resolution
of 3/100 of a wavenumber,

you can get the 3 thousandths
of a wavenumber precision in spaces. And so the dispersed
fluorescence

might not be quite
precise enough to make rotational assignments.

You can then scan through
the lines in question,

and you can use your laser
precision rather than monochrometer precision.

So this is a fantastic
thing, because just

by doing a simple, in this
case, a passive double resonance experiment, the spectrum
is completely sorted out.

And so instead of having to
face the usual classical problem

of being given everything
and trying to find a toehold to begin to unravel, to take
it apart, from the very get-go,

you have it sorted. And so this means you can deal
with much more complicated
problems right away.
OK. Now there are hybrid methods.

I said passive double resonance. I'm leading up to
double resonance where you have two lasers.

But you can also use the
monochrometer in a way. I think Sam asked this question.

Suppose you use
the micrometer not

to look at dispersed
fluorescence, but to only look at
fluorescence that

happens to occur
within a relatively narrow spectral window. And so here is a
4 track parabola.

And so what is this?  So in an [? arbitrary ?]
spectrum,

the spectrum isn't spread
out as a four track parabola. It's a bunch of lines in
a one dimensional array.

And so in this, the way that
the figure in the lecture notes

is labeled, this is wrong, as
far as Herzberg is concerned, because red is on the left.
And so here is the p for entry. Here's the r branch region. This is red.

And what's going on here? Well, a p branch always
starts out going to the red.

And if there is a
head in the p branch,

then the p branch
will turn around. And so here's the head.

And we'll continue
out to the blue. The r branch always
starts out to the blue.

And so in this region,
there will be r lines and p lines commingled.

In this region, you start
out at low j in the p branch,

and there's the higher j. Now, there are lines the
low j region of the p branch

is in the midst
a lot of traffic. All right, so there are
two kinds of experiments

you can do. You can set your monochrometer
to accept a spectral window

which is narrow. Maybe there are three or
four lines in that window.

And you can set
the monochrometer either to here or to here.

OK. And so suppose you
set your monochrometer

to accept the window
that's relatively near the end [INAUDIBLE].

And then you scan your laser. OK, well, one thing that
you would not want to do

is scan the laser in the region
where the monochrometer is set, because there would be a lot of
scattered light to go through.

And so what you will
do is scan the laser. And when you go through this
region, which is related,

which has r branch
lines commingled with the p branch lines,
which are excited over here. You're going to see some
fluorescence in this window.

And so there'll be a
few lines that appear. And they will be
associated with this.

Now this also intersects
this region here,

which might be a p branch.  So the p branch starts out going
like that and comes around.

So this might be very high
j lines in the p branch, or it might be relatively
low j lines of the r branch.

And so there will be
another region that

corresponds to the lines here. And so it'll be
another group lines.

And so you'll be selecting a few
j's in the p branch seeing them

in the r branch. You'll be selecting
something over here and you'll see them
somewhere else.

So if you set the
monochrometer at this point, there will be two little
pieces of spectrum you see.

And you know a fair
amount about them, because you have laser precision
in measuring the lines.

And you know that they're
far away from where you set the monochrometer.

And then, of course, you
do the other experiment. You now set the monochrometer
where these lines were.

And then, when you
stand in this region,

you see those lines, which
you know are related to these.

And you have laser
precision on them. So you do two
experiments, and you

get little pieces of
the r and p branch that you know are
related, and you get them

with laser precision. And so it's a very, very
effective and simple way

of doing laser-induced
fluorescence, where

by using a monochrometer,
you sort the spectrum. [? Tim ?] [? Steinley ?]
uses this a lot.

And I don't know
who invented it. I think we did it, but it's
a pretty simple technique,

and it sorts the spectrum. AUDIENCE: One thing that
you've always warned me about using
monochrometer is that you

lose an awful lot of intensity. ROBERT FIELD: Sure. AUDIENCE: And so how
much of a problem

is it for different uses
of the monochrometer? ROBERT FIELD:
Well, for this one,

you don't care that
much about resolution. The monochrometer's
slit can be pretty wide.

And so what does a
monochrometer cost you?

I mean, in a usual
experiment, you're exciting fluorescence
here, and you

have some kind of a lens
and a photomultiplier here. OK, so what fraction of the
fluorescence can you intercept?

Well, it's not unreasonable
to say that you can have a 2 inch diameter lens.

About two inches away
from the monochrometer. And so you can figure out what
fractions, what side angle that is.

So and then, if you're using
a monochrometer, or just

the bare photomultiplier,
the quantum yield of the photomultiplier
is the same. So what you really want to
do is compare the f number

of your optics for collecting
simple fluorescence and the f number of
the monochrometer.

The f number of a
monochrometer is usually for this sort of
thing it's usually 10.

F10. Sometimes you get one
that's got a bigger grading and maybe gets down to 7.5
or something like that.

The solid angle is
the [? square root ?] of is related to the
square of [INAUDIBLE]..

So you would, with a
photomultiplier close

to your fluorescence region,
see roughly 100 times

more fluorescence. Now, sometimes,
because you don't

want to get scattered
light, you put a filter here to block the laser.

That cost you a factor of 10. You don't need a filter
with the monochrometer, because it's a super filter.

And so now, then,
there's the issue of how efficient is the grading?

Is the grading 100% efficient? Well, holographic gradings are
very, very high efficiency.

And but then, there's the issue
of is it a blazed grading, and in which order you work.

So roughly, you use
a monochrometer, and you're losing
a factor of 100.

But you can calculate it. There's also how big
is the slit, and so on.

How big is the
slit, and how big is the photomultiplier and so on.

OK so you can also do active
double resonance experiments. I mean, using the monochrometer,
it satisfies my rule

that you want something
that's always going to work. Because what is a monochrometer? It's a grading in a box.

And if the grading drive
isn't working well, you knew that before you
started the experiment.

And if the photomultiplier,
isn't working, well, it's the same
thing you do with LIF. So it's a pretty
certain thing to work.

Whereas, especially
in the 1960s and 70s, the laser was pretty
surely not going to work.

And if it was working, you want
to get data and do something. And so having two lasers
that are working was hard.

And so having a passive
double resonance scheme is a great way to do business.

But you can also do
something like this. So you would say here,
and that state selects.

That's basically the same thing
as the dispersed fluorescence experiment. And then you scan
the second laser.

So this laser is fixed. And now you scan this laser. And you look either at dips
in the fluorescence from this,

or is the appearance
of fluorescence to the blue of what you
would have gotten from here.

And you see nothing but
[INAUDIBLE] differences.

And that's a fantastic thing. And this is also better
than dispersed fluorescence, because you have
laser resolution.

And this one has
Doppler selected, and so there's no
Doppler width either. And so it's much better
than dispersed fluorescence.

But the problem is it requires
two tunable lasers working. And in the days of CW lasers,
that was always a problem.

In the days of YAG
pump die lasers, it's not so much of a problem.

Because they're
both being pumped by the same YAG laser, and the
die lasers are pretty passive.

And so you can do
a double resonance. And there are even people
who, with CW lasers,
now do quadruple resonance. So it's not impossible.

It's just asking for trouble. So you can do these
two laser experiments.

There are many kinds of
two laser experiments.

And maybe we'll talk
about that someday. OK, so now, you have a
technique that enables

you to simplify the spectrum. So the assignment, instead of
being an elaborate exercise

in bad recognition, is have
this on a silver platter. And so one of the
things that you do

is say, OK, I'm
capable of dealing with a far more
complicated spectrum

than I would have been
by classical methods. And so that's the
masochistic approach.

If complexity is hard, well,
I strip away the complexity

by doing double resonance,
and I go for new complexity, which is much worse. That's what I do.

OK. But let's talk about what
kinds of new complexity

you're going to encounter. I mean, everything I've been
talking about up til now has pretended that molecules
are in electronic states called

[? singlet ?]
signal plus states. That they don't have
any fine structure. And so we haven't thought
about details about what

electronic state it is. We've only asked,
well, what j is the transition, and sometimes
a little bit about what

vibrational level. But what about the symmetry? And if you have a state that's
not [? singlet ?] signal plus,

there's going to
be extra levels. And those are going to make
the problem more complicated.

So we have lambda, which is
the orbital angular momentum

projection of the
inner nuclear axis. And this is a source of
confusion for a lot of people

because lambda is
a projection of l.

The total orbital
angular momentum. But this is a not
round molecule.

L is quenched by
the not roundness. There is no L. But the not roundness
has as a symmetry.

You have a unique axis. Or you can think of
this as a Stark effect,

where you have a certain
symmetry electric field. It mixes all l's, but preserves
the projection quantum

number, which is lambda. So lambda is usually good, and
l is usually not even relevant.

And we have spin. We have the projection
of the spin.

So the spin, unlike
l, the spin is not destroyed by the lack
of spherical symmetry.

And that reflects
the fact that there are no spatial
coordinates for the spin.

The spin is just
some mythical beast that physicists have
invented for us.

And it doesn't know about
space without being isotropic

or other molecules
not being grounded. So we have these
quantum numbers.

And omega is lambda plus
sigma, or let's call jz.

Now, you might think
this is a trivial thing,

and in some ways, it's trivial,
but in some ways it's special.

Lambda and sigma are
electronic quantum numbers. J is from the of the
rotational wave function.

So we have this j omega m.  That's something that's distinct
from the electronic wave

function. It happens that omega has to
be equal to lambda plus sigma, but it really has two
different sources.

And a lot of people
don't understand that.

OK. So we're going to have states
that have additional quantum numbers.

And so it would be nice
to be able to record a spectrum in such a way that
we can determine these quantum

numbers for both the upper
and lower electronic state. And the most important method
for making such assignments

is finding the lowest
j lines in each of the rotational branches.

And so I'm going to talk
about that for a while.
How much longer do I have? Not very long. Not very long at all.

So we make little diagrams that
represent the energy intervals. Now in the notes, the diagram
is a little simpler than this.

This is a [? singlet ?]
signal plus state. And let's say this is
a single pos state.

And so we put onto this
labels for j and [INAUDIBLE]..

And now for pi, we
have j equals 1,

and we have minus
parity and plus parity. And then for j equals two, we
have plus parity minus parity.

So a single tie state
is really two states,

and the lowest j is m and
the parity alternates with j,

and they alternate in such a way
that you have these two paired end, the lower component
and the upper component,
that vary this way.

So the first thing you do-- the reason you draw
these diagrams is it enables you to figure out what
will be the lowest j lines.

I mean, they're very,
very powerful things. But as soon as you
have parity and j,

you can draw what will be
the possible transitions. And so you have to go plus
to minus, or minus to plus,
so you have a transition there. You have a transition there.
And you have a transition there.
So this is our zero. This is p2, and this is q1.
Those are the first lines.

And so for a
[? singlet single ?] single pi, that's what you can
see if you had a--

and you can work on what
the pattern of first lines would be for any symmetry.
Now, there's other things here. Plus, minus, plus, minus. Minus, plus, minus.

There is another way
of labeling the levels. It's called EF symmetry.

And what happens is you multiply
the parity by minus 1 to the j,

and you've regularized things. So if all of these levels are
e, and all of these levels are f, and what you
discover is r and p

branches that are always ee,
and q branches are always ef.

As opposed to this
less convenient-- I mean, you can
remember this diagram,

but this is much more
useful for thinking about what the spectrum [INAUDIBLE]. So you make these
little diagrams,

and they tell you what
to look for in order to make definite assignments.

And they also tell
you that you'd

like to be able to organize
things according to patterns. Pattern forming quantum numbers.

And so if you look at the
bottom of page 5 of the notes,

there's a transition
between a case, v triplet signal state by
case a triplet [? pi ?] state.

And in a case b state, the
pattern forming quantum number is n, in the case a state,
the pattern forming quantum

is j, the rotational energy
levels arrange themselves according to b 1 n
plus 1 in this state,

and b effective
omega jj plus 1 here.

So we have the energy
levels that are always expressed as a quantum
number times a quantum

number plus 1 times a constant. And for case a, you have
a rotational constant,

which is maybe
slightly different from the different omega components. But you have this
way of pretending

to have a singlet sigma states. So you're reducing things to
the more fundamental unit,

and then you find the
patterns you need. And so that's a rushed version
of how you use lasers to things

out. And the next time,

and that building [? effect ?]
